Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: Full-Scale Development: Living Liquid: Creating Interactive Visualization Tools to Explore Ocean Datasets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will pioneer a critical new genre of science exhibit: interactive visualizations that engage visitors in the process of scientific inquiry. The capability to create advanced visualizations of large scale data sets in an interactive platform was developed in a prior pathways project. The interactive platform will be installed in a museum/science center setting in this full scale development project and will be assessed to determine how visitors utilize the interactive advanced visualizations of large data sets to explore for themselves, scientific issues involving the world's oceans.

The display, called Living Liquid, will develop visualizations from three large data sets provided by science partners in the project involving ocean ecology, with programming of the data developed in the pathways demonstration project. The visualizations of this data will be viewed by visitors to the Exploratorium in San Francisco on an interactive display table. The data display allows users to see data elements displayed in the geographic location from which they were found. Unlike other efforts to create visual displays for the public focused on a one-way display or that require guided mediation, users of the Living Liquid platform can direct the investigation of the data themselves. Unlike a screen at home or a tablet, the display format is intended to promote interaction and dialogue among the groups that form around the display as a self-supporting form of investigation. The strength of table design is in the physical and digital interfaces built into the display that make the exploration of data appealing, intuitive and meaningful, to evoke questions and comparisons and make patterns in the data discoverable by the users.

The three areas chosen for the display table from science partners in the project include: "Plankton Patterns," an adaptation of the MIT Darwin Project simulation, which is used by scientists around the world to study what types of plankton live in the oceans and why they are there. On the Viz Table, this simulation will be adapted so visitors can explore the diversity and number of plankton through real glass lenses, a unique feature of this visualization effort. "Genetic Rhythms" is based on data from the Center for Microbial Oceanography Research and Education (C-MORE) which studies what genes microscopic ocean creatures turn off and on under different environmental conditions. On the Viz Table, visitors will be able to explore the activity of different genes as the ocean conditions change throughout a day. "Ocean Tracks" uses data from the TOPP project at Stanford University, which is studying the migratory paths of large marine creatures in relation to environmental conditions. This visualization will allow visitors to follow the paths of marine creatures such as sharks, turtles, or salmon and how they correlate to conditions such as temperature gradients or ocean currents. The data displays are separate from each other because, how data is collected and studied is different for each science partner.

The project will assess how the public interacts with the large data sets through the specially designed visualizations and the extent to which the visualization enhances the understanding of the data. It will also assess how viewers use the data through the interactive functions on the visualization, controlling their own explorations of real scientific data to understand and explore what the data tells them about issues of ocean ecology. The project includes scientist-led public programs using the visualizations to explore science topics and issues identified by the data through the visualization. It also includes a research study on how informal learners can use data visualizations to support self-directed or group inquiry and learning.

The project provides opportunities for professional development for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) professionals in how to use advanced visualization capabilities to communicate research methods and findings to the public and in their own work. One of the challenges in the emerging use of large data sets is bringing together computer scientists, cognitive scientists, and graphic designers with disciplinary experts to understand how to create and interpret visualizations of large data repositories. Major insights on the use of color, perception or effective interaction do not seem to extend beyond a given field. Consequently there is a need to provide opportunities for STEM professionals to learn about effective visualization techniques and user-testing and evaluation. This project provides the opportunity for cross-disciplinary professionals to share knowledge and get training while focused on a goal of creating visualization for the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Living Liquid was a project of the Exploratorium and the Center for Visualization at the University of California at Davis which sought to engage the public with new research on ocean ecosystems through scientific visualizations. In collaboration with science partners at MIT, Stanford University, and the Center for Microbial Oceanography Research and Education (C-MORE) based at the University of Hawai’I, the project was designed to address an increasingly critical need to create scientific visualizations that can be explored by the public. Visualizations, computer-generated visual representations, are one of the most critical tools for making discoveries with scientific data. As the amount of data increases exponentially, the public is increasingly dependent on visualizations of these complex datasets to understand themselves and the world around them.

A number of projects have been done to present scientific visualizations to the public, but there had been little work to design visualizations that let the public explore visualizations the way scientists do – as tools for finding new patterns and raising new questions. Living Liquid pioneered interactive visualizations that engage visitors in the process of scientific inquiry—asking productive questions, and analyzing and interpreting data. To date, the focus of inquiry-based exhibits had been on hands-on exploration of physical variables such as weight. But as the phenomena explored by science expand in the era of big data, so must the types of inquiry-based exhibits developed by informal learning institutions. Living Liquid had the following goals:

1. To advance public understanding of ocean ecosystems and data inquiry skills.

2. To increase the capacity of STEM professionals (both ISE developers and research scientists) to develop visualizations.

3. To advance STEM professionals’ knowledge of how to engage the public in inquiry with visualizations. 

These project goals were met through the following project deliverables: 

Three table-sized interactive visualizations of ocean data.

Living Liquid  produced three different visualizations with large marine datasets: (1) Mapping Migrations reveals the “highways” large marine creatures travel using data from Stanford and the Tagging of Pacific Predators Project; (2) Plankton Populations shows how the ocean is defined by regions of microscopic life that change in response to the environment using data from the MIT Darwin Project; and (3) Sea of Genes follows the activity of marine creatures’ genes in response to sunlight and other conditions using data from the University of Hawai’i. Formative and summative evaluations of Plankton Populations and Mapping Migrations have shown visitors learn key ocean concepts and are engaged in inquiry at these visualizations. The third visualization, Sea of Genes, was difficult for visitors to use and therefore did not foster inquiry.

Research study on supporting data inquiry.

Living Liquid included a learning research study on supporting data inquiry with interactive visualizations. Using a variety of methods including qualitative coding of visitors’ think aloud data and quantitative analysis of visitor interactions at multiple versions of each visualization, the project identified promises and pitfalls of using visualizations as a means of engaging informal science learners with authentic scientific datasets. Living Liquid found:

1. Most visitors did not engage in sustained inquiry with these visualizations

2. Simplifying decoding (i.e. helping visitors more easily map symbol to meaning) is an important part of lowering the barrier to initial data inquiry

3. When visitor do spend the time, they ask productive questions (i.e., questions that are answerable with the data visualized), and use the visualizations to answer their questions.

STEM professional development and graduate student training.

Living Liquid used the creation of visualization-based exhibits as an opportunity for STEM professional development on visualization design. Seven computer science graduate students from U.C. Davis and six partner scientists from MIT, University of Hawai’i, and Stanford were embedded on the project team throughout the course of the project. Evaluation of professional development by outside evaluator Inverness Research found that the project had tremendous impact on the knowledge and practice of team members, and results are being prepared for publication and dissemination.

Publications. Four publications resulting from the Living Liquid project include peer-reviewed publications on adapting visualizations in computer science journals (Ma, Liao, Frazier, Hauser, & Kostis, 2012;  Ma et al., 2012; Hsueh et al., 2016) and a conference paper in educational research (Ma, 2013). There will be further publications disseminating the findings of the research study and professional development surveys.

Broad dissemination to enhance scientific and technological understanding. PIs Dr. Jennifer Frazier and Living Liquid co-PIs Dr. Joyce Ma and Dr. Kwan-Liu Ma Ma have given 20 invited presentations at meetings of computer scientists, biologists, and educators such as IEEE Vis, Pacific Vis, the Gordon Research Conference on Visualization in Science and Education, and the NSF Cyberlearning Summit.
